document_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Aspergillus fumigatus Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station
summary_full: This study presents the draft genome sequences of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4, isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). These strains were previously found to be significantly more lethal in a zebrafish model and more resistant to UV radiation compared to clinical isolates. The genome sequencing was performed using Illumina HiSeq2500, and the resulting reads were assembled using the MaSuRCA genome assembler. The draft genome of ISSFT-021 consists of 301 scaffolds totaling 28.5 Mb, while IF1SW-F4 has 208 scaffolds totaling 28.2 Mb. These sequences are deposited in public databases and aim to facilitate investigations into the molecular mechanisms behind the enhanced virulence and radiation resistance of ISS-isolated A. fumigatus strains, which could inform countermeasures for astronaut health.
key_findings: Draft genome sequences for two Aspergillus fumigatus strains (ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4) isolated from the International Space Station have been assembled.
The ISS-isolated strains exhibit significantly greater virulence and UV resistance compared to clinical isolates.
The genome assembly for ISSFT-021 contains 301 scaffolds totaling 28.5 Mb with an N50 of 275.5 kb.
The genome assembly for IF1SW-F4 contains 208 scaffolds totaling 28.2 Mb with an N50 of 367.4 kb.
The deposited genome sequences will enable research into the molecular basis of enhanced pathogenicity and radiation resistance in space-isolated fungi.
future_research_fields: Investigating the genetic basis for enhanced virulence in space-isolated Aspergillus fumigatus strains.
Exploring the molecular mechanisms of increased UV radiation resistance in these strains.
Developing countermeasures to protect astronaut health from potentially more virulent fungal pathogens in space environments.
Comparative genomics of ISS-isolated fungi versus terrestrial clinical isolates to identify unique adaptations.

conclusions: The draft genome sequences of the two Aspergillus fumigatus strains isolated from the ISS have been successfully assembled and made publicly available. These sequences are crucial for understanding the molecular basis of their enhanced virulence and radiation resistance, which could have significant implications for astronaut health and the development of countermeasures in space environments.
impact_statement: This study provides the genomic foundation to investigate how spaceflight may enhance the virulence of opportunistic fungal pathogens, crucial for ensuring astronaut safety and developing effective countermeasures.
